<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Lil_Wayne skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Lil Wayne</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-blp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-blp (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-blp</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_musical_artist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox musical artist (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox musical artist</a> 
<b>Dwayne Michael Carter, Jr.</b> (born September 27, 1982), known by his <a href="/wiki/Stage_name" title="Stage name">stage name</a> <b>Lil Wayne</b>, is an American rapper from <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans" title="New Orleans">New Orleans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>. In 1991, at the age of nine, Lil Wayne joined <a href="/wiki/Cash_Money_Records" title="Cash Money Records">Cash Money Records</a> as the youngest member of the label, and half of the duo <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_B.G.%27z&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The B.G.'z (page does not exist)">The B.G.'z</a>, alongside fellow New Orleans-based <a href="/wiki/Rapper" title="Rapper" class="mw-redirect">rapper</a> <a href="/wiki/B.G._(rapper)" title="B.G. (rapper)">Lil' Doogie</a>. In 1996, Lil Wayne formed the <a href="/wiki/Southern_hip_hop" title="Southern hip hop">Southern hip hop</a> group <a href="/wiki/Hot_Boys" title="Hot Boys">Hot Boys</a>, with his Cash Money label-mates <a href="/wiki/Juvenile_(rapper)" title="Juvenile (rapper)">Juvenile</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turk_(rapper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turk (rapper) (page does not exist)">Young Turk</a> and Lil' Doogie (who now went by B.G.). Hot Boys debuted with <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Get_It_How_U_Live!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Get It How U Live! (page does not exist)">Get It How U Live!</a></i> that same year. Lil Wayne gained most of his success with the group's major selling album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Guerrilla_Warfare_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guerrilla Warfare (album) (page does not exist)">Guerrilla Warfare</a></i> (1999). Along with being the flagship artist of Cash Money Records, Lil Wayne is also the <a href="/wiki/Chief_executive_officer" title="Chief executive officer">chief executive officer</a> (CEO) of his own imprint, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Young_Money_Entertainment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Young Money Entertainment (page does not exist)">Young Money Entertainment</a>, which he founded in 2005.
</p><p>Lil Wayne's debut studio album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Block_Is_Hot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Block Is Hot (page does not exist)">Tha Block Is Hot</a></i> (1999), was <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" title="Music recording sales certification">certified platinum</a> by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recording_Industry_Association_of_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recording Industry Association of America (page does not exist)">Recording Industry Association of America</a> (RIAA). His following albums, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lights_Out_(Lil_Wayne_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lights Out (Lil Wayne album) (page does not exist)">Lights Out</a></i> (2000) and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=500_Degreez&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="500 Degreez (page does not exist)">500 Degreez</a></i> (2002), were <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" title="Music recording sales certification">certified gold</a>. He reached higher popularity with <i><a href="/wiki/Tha_Carter" title="Tha Carter">Tha Carter</a></i> (2004), which was led by the single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Go_D.J.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Go D.J. (page does not exist)">Go D.J.</a>", also appearing on <a href="/wiki/Destiny%27s_Child" title="Destiny's Child">Destiny's Child</a>'s top ten single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Soldier_(Destiny%27s_Child_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soldier (Destiny's Child song) (page does not exist)">Soldier</a>", that same year. The album was followed by <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Carter_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Carter II (page does not exist)">Tha Carter II</a></i> (2005) and several <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mixtape&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mixtape (page does not exist)">mixtapes</a> and collaborations throughout 2006 and 2007. <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Carter_III&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Carter III (page does not exist)">Tha Carter III</a></i> (2008) became Lil Wayne's most successful album to date, with first-week sales of over 1 million copies in the United States. It included the number-one single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Lollipop_(Lil_Wayne_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lollipop (Lil Wayne song) (page does not exist)">Lollipop</a>", as well as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Milli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Milli (page does not exist)">A Milli</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Got_Money&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Got Money (page does not exist)">Got Money</a>", and won the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammy Award</a> for <a href="/wiki/Best_Rap_Album" title="Best Rap Album" class="mw-redirect">Best Rap Album</a>.
</p><p>Following the success of <i>Tha Carter III</i>, Lil Wayne decided to record a <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">rock</a> album titled <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rebirth_(Lil_Wayne_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rebirth (Lil Wayne album) (page does not exist)">Rebirth</a></i>, in which he is featured playing guitar and singing with the help of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Auto-Tune&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Auto-Tune (page does not exist)">Auto-Tune</a>. The album, released in 2010, was certified gold by the RIAA, despite a generally negative critical response. In March 2010, Lil Wayne began serving an 8-month prison sentence in New York after being convicted of criminal possession of a weapon stemming from an incident in July 2007. Wayne's eighth  album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am_Not_a_Human_Being&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am Not a Human Being (page does not exist)">I Am Not a Human Being</a></i> (2010), was released during his prison sentence. His 2011 album and first following his release, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Carter_IV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Carter IV (page does not exist)">Tha Carter IV</a></i>, sold 964,000 copies in its first week of availability in the United States. It featured the singles "<a href="/w/index.php?title=6_Foot_7_Foot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="6 Foot 7 Foot (page does not exist)">6 Foot 7 Foot</a>", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=How_to_Love&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="How to Love (page does not exist)">How to Love</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=She_Will&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="She Will (page does not exist)">She Will</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> On September 27, 2012, Lil Wayne passed <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">Elvis Presley</a> as the male with the most entries on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a> chart with 109 songs.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span></h2>
<p>Dwayne Michael Carter, Jr. was born on September 27, 1982, and grew up in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hollygrove,_New_Orleans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hollygrove, New Orleans (page does not exist)">Hollygrove</a> neighborhood of <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans" title="New Orleans">New Orleans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-allmusicguide_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allmusicguide-3">[3]</a></sup> He was born when his mother, a cook, was 19 years old. His parents divorced when he was 2, and his father permanently abandoned the family. Although Lil Wayne and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Birdman_(entertainer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Birdman (entertainer) (page does not exist)">Birdman</a> have a father–son relationship and Birdman calls Carter his son, Lil Wayne’s biological father and namesake (Dwayne Carter) is still alive. Lil Wayne has also spoken about his deceased stepfather, Rabbit, who he has said he considers his real father. Carter has a tattoo dedicated to Rabbit, who was murdered before Carter became a star.<sup id="cite_ref-AP_Respect_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AP_Respect-4">[4]</a></sup> Carter enrolled in the gifted program of Lafayette Elementary School and in the drama club of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eleanor_McMain_Secondary_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eleanor McMain Secondary School (page does not exist)">Eleanor McMain Secondary School</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Best_MC_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Best_MC-5">[5]</a></sup> Lil Wayne attended McMain in the early 1990s for two years. He moved to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marion_Abramson_Senior_High_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marion Abramson Senior High School (page does not exist)">Marion Abramson Senior High School</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a CBS interview with <a href="/wiki/Katie_Couric" title="Katie Couric">Katie Couric</a>, Wayne described why he goes by the name of "Wayne" instead of his given name, Dwayne. Carter explained, "I dropped the D because I'm a junior and my father is living and he's not in my life and he's never been in my life. So I don't want to be Dwayne, I'd rather be Wayne". Couric asked Wayne if his father knew of this and Wayne replied with a smile, "He knows now."<sup id="cite_ref-Couric_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Couric-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>He wrote his first rap song at age eight.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-8">[8]</a></sup> In the summer of 1991, he met <a href="/wiki/Birdman_(rapper)" title="Birdman (rapper)">Bryan Williams</a>, rapper and owner of <a href="/wiki/Cash_Money_Records" title="Cash Money Records">Cash Money Records</a>. Carter recorded freestyle raps on Williams's answering machine, leading him to mentor the young Carter and include him in Cash Money-distributed songs. He also recorded his first ever <a href="/wiki/Collaboration" title="Collaboration">collaboration</a> album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=True_Story_(BGz_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="True Story (BGz album) (page does not exist)">True Story</a></i> with rapper <a href="/wiki/B.G._(rapper)" title="B.G. (rapper)">B.G.</a>. At the time, Carter was 11, and B.G. was 14, and was billed as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_B.G.%27z&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The B.G.'z (page does not exist)">The B.G.'z</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-new_yorker_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-new_yorker-9">[9]</a></sup> When he was 12, he played the part of the <a href="/wiki/Tin_Woodman" title="Tin Woodman">Tin Man</a> in his middle school drama club's production of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wiz" title="The Wiz">The Wiz</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-10">[10]</a></sup> At age 12, he accidentally shot himself with a 9&#160;mm handgun, and off-duty police officer Robert Hoobler drove him to the hospital.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> At McMain Magnet School, Carter was an honor student, but he dropped out at the age of 14 to focus on a musical career.<sup id="cite_ref-Vibe_Nov_2007_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vibe_Nov_2007-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1996.E2.80.9399:_Career_beginnings_and_Hot_Boys">1996–99: Career beginnings and Hot Boys</span></h3>
<p>In 1996, Carter joined the <a href="/wiki/Hot_Boys" title="Hot Boys">Hot Boys</a> along with rappers <a href="/wiki/Juvenile_(rapper)" title="Juvenile (rapper)">Juvenile</a>, <a href="/wiki/B.G._(rapper)" title="B.G. (rapper)">B.G.</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turk_(rapper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turk (rapper) (page does not exist)">Turk</a>. At age 15, Carter was the youngest member at the time. Hot Boys' debut album <i>Get It How U Live!</i> was released the same year, followed in 1999 by the group's major-label debut <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Guerrilla_Warfare_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guerrilla Warfare (album) (page does not exist)">Guerrilla Warfare</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-allmusicguide_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allmusicguide-3">[3]</a></sup> which reached No. 1 on the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Billboard_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Billboard (magazine) (page does not exist)">Billboard</a></i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Top_R%26B/Hip-Hop_Albums&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Top R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Albums (page does not exist)">Top R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Albums</a> chart and No. 5 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200">Billboard 200</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Hot_Boys_Album_Charts_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hot_Boys_Album_Charts-13">[13]</a></sup> During their career, the Hot Boys had two charting singles, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=We_on_Fire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We on Fire (page does not exist)">We on Fire</a>" from <i>Get It How U Live!</i> and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Need_a_Hot_Girl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Need a Hot Girl (page does not exist)">I Need a Hot Girl</a>" from <i>Guerrilla Warfare</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Carter was also featured on Juvenile's single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Back_That_Azz_Up&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Back That Azz Up (page does not exist)">Back That Azz Up</a>", which reached No. 18 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">Billboard Hot 100</a> and No. 5 on the Hot R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Singles &amp; Tracks.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> <i>Let 'Em Burn</i>, a compilation album of unreleased tracks recorded during 1999 and 2000, came out in 2003, several years after the group disbanded.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> It reached No. 3 on the Top R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Albums chart and No. 14 on the <i>Billboard</i> 200.<sup id="cite_ref-Hot_Boys_Album_Charts_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hot_Boys_Album_Charts-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1999.E2.80.932002:_Tha_Block_Is_Hot.2C_Lights_Out.2C_and_500_Degreez">1999–2002: <i>Tha Block Is Hot</i>, <i>Lights Out</i>, and <i>500 Degreez</i></span></h3>
<p>Carter's debut solo album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Block_Is_Hot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Block Is Hot (page does not exist)">Tha Block Is Hot</a></i> was released when he was 17 and featured significant contributions from the <a href="/wiki/Hot_Boys" title="Hot Boys">Hot Boys</a>. It debuted at No. 3 on the Billboard 200 and was later certified platinum by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=RIAA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="RIAA (page does not exist)">RIAA</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-allmusicguide_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allmusicguide-3">[3]</a></sup> The album earned Carter a 1999 <i><a href="/wiki/The_Source_(magazine)" title="The Source (magazine)">Source</a></i> magazine nomination for "Best New Artist",<sup id="cite_ref-cash_money_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cash_money-17">[17]</a></sup> and also became a Top Ten hit.<sup id="cite_ref-allmusicguide_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allmusicguide-3">[3]</a></sup> The lead single was "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Block_Is_Hot_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Block Is Hot (song) (page does not exist)">Tha Block Is Hot</a>". After the release of <i>Tha Block is Hot</i>, Carter was featured on the single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Bling_Bling_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bling Bling (song) (page does not exist)">Bling Bling</a>", with B.G., Juvenile, and Big Tymers. His verse appeared only on the radio version of the song, while on the album version he performed on the chorus.
</p><p>His 2000 follow-up album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lights_Out_(Lil_Wayne_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lights Out (Lil Wayne album) (page does not exist)">Lights Out</a></i> failed to attain the level of success achieved by his debut<sup id="cite_ref-allmusicguide_3-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allmusicguide-3">[3]</a></sup> but was certified gold by RIAA.<sup id="cite_ref-riaa_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-riaa-18">[18]</a></sup> Critics noted the lack of coherent narratives in his verses as evidence that he had yet to mature to the level of his fellow Hot Boys.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> The lead single was "Get Off the Corner", which was noticed for an improvement in its lyrical content and style. The second single, which received less attention, was "Shine" featuring the Hot Boys. Near the release of <i>Lights Out</i>, Lil Wayne was featured on the single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Number_One_Stunna&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Number One Stunna (page does not exist)">Number One Stunna</a>" with <a href="/wiki/Big_Tymers" title="Big Tymers">Big Tymers</a> and Juvenile, which peaked at No. 24 on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hot_Rap_Tracks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hot Rap Tracks (page does not exist)">Hot Rap Tracks</a> chart.
</p><p>Lil Wayne's third album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=500_Degreez&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="500 Degreez (page does not exist)">500 Degreez</a></i>, released in 2002, followed the format of his previous two, with significant contributions from the Hot Boys and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mannie_Fresh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mannie Fresh (page does not exist)">Mannie Fresh</a>. While being certified gold like its predecessor,<sup id="cite_ref-riaa_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-riaa-18">[18]</a></sup> it also failed to match the success of his debut.<sup id="cite_ref-allmusicguide_3-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allmusicguide-3">[3]</a></sup> The title was a reference to the recently estranged Hot Boys member Juvenile's recording, <i><a href="/wiki/400_Degreez" title="400 Degreez">400 Degreez</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> The lead single was "Way of Life" which failed to match the success of his previous singles. After the release of <i>500 Degreez</i>, Wayne was featured on the single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Neva_Get_Enuf&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Neva Get Enuf (page does not exist)">Neva Get Enuf</a>" by <a href="/wiki/3LW" title="3LW">3LW</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2003.E2.80.9306:_Tha_Carter.2C_Tha_Carter_II.2C_and_Like_Father.2C_Like_Son">2003–06: <i>Tha Carter</i>, <i>Tha Carter II</i>, and <i>Like Father, Like Son</i></span></h3>
<p>In the summer of 2004, Wayne's album <i><a href="/wiki/Tha_Carter" title="Tha Carter">Tha Carter</a></i> was released, marking what critics considered advancement in his rapping style and lyrical themes.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> In addition, the album's cover art featured the debut of Wayne's now-signature <a href="/wiki/Dreadlocks" title="Dreadlocks">dreadlocks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-allmusicguide_3-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allmusicguide-3">[3]</a></sup> <i>Tha Carter</i> gained Wayne significant recognition, selling 878,000 copies in the United States, while the single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Go_DJ&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Go DJ (page does not exist)">Go DJ</a>" became a Top 5 Hit on the R&amp;B/Hip-Hop chart.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> After the release of <i>Tha Carter</i>, Lil Wayne was featured in <a href="/wiki/Destiny%27s_Child" title="Destiny's Child">Destiny's Child's</a> single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Soldier_(Destiny%27s_Child_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soldier (Destiny's Child song) (page does not exist)">Soldier</a>" with <a href="/wiki/T.I." title="T.I.">T.I.</a>, which peaked at No. 3 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">Billboard Hot 100</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hot_R%26B/Hip-Hop_Songs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hot R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Songs (page does not exist)">Hot R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Songs</a> charts.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Carter_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Carter II (page does not exist)">Tha Carter II</a></i>, the follow-up to the original <i>Tha Carter</i> album, was released in December 2005, this time without production by longtime <a href="/wiki/Cash_Money_Records" title="Cash Money Records">Cash Money Records</a> producer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mannie_Fresh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mannie Fresh (page does not exist)">Mannie Fresh</a>, who had since left the label. <i>Tha Carter II</i> sold more than 238,000 copies in its first week of release, debuting at No. 2 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200"><i>Billboard</i> 200</a> albums chart, and went on to sell 2,000,000 copies worldwide. The lead single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Fireman_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fireman (song) (page does not exist)">Fireman</a>" became a hit in the US, peaking at 32 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart. Other singles included "Grown Man" with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Currensy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Currensy (page does not exist)">Currensy</a>, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Hustler_Musik&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hustler Musik (page does not exist)">Hustler Musik</a>", and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Shooter_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shooter (song) (page does not exist)">Shooter</a>" with R&amp;B singer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robin_Thicke&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robin Thicke (page does not exist)">Robin Thicke</a>. Lil Wayne also appeared on a remix of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bobby_V&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bobby V (page does not exist)">Bobby Valentino's</a> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Tell_Me_(Bobby_Valentino_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tell Me (Bobby Valentino song) (page does not exist)">Tell Me</a>", which rose to No. 13 on the U.S. R&amp;B Charts. In 2005, Lil Wayne was named president of Cash Money, and in the same year he founded <a href="/w/index.php?title=Young_Money_Entertainment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Young Money Entertainment (page does not exist)">Young Money Entertainment</a> as an imprint of Cash Money.<sup id="cite_ref-Lil_Big_Man_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lil_Big_Man-25">[25]</a></sup> However, as of late 2007, Lil Wayne reported that he has stepped down from the management of both labels and has handed management of Young Money over to Cortez Bryant.<sup id="cite_ref-Weezy_F_Baby_Uncut_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weezy_F_Baby_Uncut-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2006, Lil Wayne collaborated with rapper <a href="/wiki/Birdman_(rapper)" title="Birdman (rapper)">Birdman</a> for the album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Like_Father,_Like_Son_(Birdman_and_Lil_Wayne_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Like Father, Like Son (Birdman and Lil Wayne album) (page does not exist)">Like Father, Like Son</a></i>, whose first single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Stuntin%27_Like_My_Daddy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stuntin' Like My Daddy (page does not exist)">Stuntin' Like My Daddy</a>", reached No. 21 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">Billboard Hot 100</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2006.E2.80.9308:_Mixtapes_and_collaborations">2006–08: Mixtapes and collaborations</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:LIL%27_WAYNE.jpg" title="File:LIL' WAYNE.jpg">File:LIL' WAYNE.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Lil Wayne performing at Voodoo Music Experience in 2008.</div></div></div>
<p>Instead of a follow-up solo album, Lil Wayne reached his audience through a plethora of mixtapes and guest appearances on a variety of pop and hip-hop singles.<sup id="cite_ref-allmusicguide_3-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-allmusicguide-3">[3]</a></sup> Of his many mixtapes, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dedication_2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dedication 2 (page does not exist)">Dedication 2</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Da_Drought_3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Da Drought 3 (page does not exist)">Da Drought 3</a></i> received the most media exposure and critical review. <i>Dedication 2</i>, released in 2006, paired Lil Wayne with DJ Drama and contained the acclaimed socially conscious track "Georgia Bush," in which Lil Wayne critiqued former US president <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_W._Bush&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George W. Bush (page does not exist)">George W. Bush</a>'s response to the effects of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hurricane_Katrina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hurricane Katrina (page does not exist)">Hurricane Katrina</a> on the city of New Orleans. <i>Da Drought 3</i> was released the following year and was available for free legal download. It contained Lil Wayne rapping over a variety of beats from recent hits by other musicians. Numerous of features in prominent hip-hop magazines such as <i><a href="/wiki/XXL_(magazine)" title="XXL (magazine)">XXL</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/Vibe_(magazine)" title="Vibe (magazine)">Vibe</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-Vibe_Nov_2007_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vibe_Nov_2007-12">[12]</a></sup> covered the mixtape. Christian Hoard of <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> magazine considered the mixtapes <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Da_Drought_3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Da Drought 3 (page does not exist)">Da Drought 3</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Drought_Is_Over_2_(The_Carter_3_Sessions)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Drought Is Over 2 (The Carter 3 Sessions) (page does not exist)">The Drought Is Over 2 (The Carter 3 Sessions)</a></i> "among the best albums of 2007."<sup id="cite_ref-Best_MC_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Best_MC-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite no album release for two years, Lil Wayne appeared in numerous singles as a featured performer, including "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Gimme_That&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gimme That (page does not exist)">Gimme That</a>" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chris_Brown_(American_singer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chris Brown (American singer) (page does not exist)">Chris Brown</a>, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Make_It_Rain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Make It Rain (page does not exist)">Make It Rain</a>" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fat_Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fat Joe (page does not exist)">Fat Joe</a>, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=You_(Lloyd_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="You (Lloyd song) (page does not exist)">You</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Lloyd_(singer)" title="Lloyd (singer)">Lloyd</a>, and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Takin%27_Over&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Takin' Over (page does not exist)">We Takin' Over</a>" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=DJ_Khaled&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DJ Khaled (page does not exist)">DJ Khaled</a> (also featuring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Akon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Akon (page does not exist)">Akon</a>, <a href="/wiki/T.I." title="T.I.">T.I.</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rick_Ross&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rick Ross (page does not exist)">Rick Ross</a>, Fat Joe, and Birdman), "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Duffle_Bag_Boy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Duffle Bag Boy (page does not exist)">Duffle Bag Boy</a>" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Playaz_Circle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Playaz Circle (page does not exist)">Playaz Circle</a>, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Sweetest_Girl_(Dollar_Bill)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sweetest Girl (Dollar Bill) (page does not exist)">Sweetest Girl (Dollar Bill)</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Wyclef_Jean" title="Wyclef Jean">Wyclef Jean</a> (also featuring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Akon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Akon (page does not exist)">Akon</a>), and the remix to "<a href="/w/index.php?title=I%27m_So_Hood&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I'm So Hood (page does not exist)">I'm So Hood</a>" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=DJ_Khaled&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DJ Khaled (page does not exist)">DJ Khaled</a> (also featuring <a href="/w/index.php?title=T-Pain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="T-Pain (page does not exist)">T-Pain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Young_Jeezy" title="Young Jeezy">Young Jeezy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ludacris" title="Ludacris">Ludacris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Busta_Rhymes" title="Busta Rhymes">Busta Rhymes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Big_Boi" title="Big Boi">Big Boi</a>, Fat Joe, Birdman, and Rick Ross). All these singles charted within the top 20 spots on the <i>Billboard</i> <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">Hot 100</a>, Hot Rap Tracks, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hot_R%26B/Hip-Hop_Songs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hot R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Songs (page does not exist)">Hot R&amp;B/Hip-Hop Songs</a> charts. On Birdman's 2007 album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=5_*_Stunna&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="5 * Stunna (page does not exist)">5 * Stunna</a></i>, Lil Wayne appeared on the singles "<a href="/w/index.php?title=100_Million&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="100 Million (page does not exist)">100 Million</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Run_This&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Run This (page does not exist)">I Run This</a>" among several other tracks. Wayne also appeared on tracks from albums <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Getback&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Getback (page does not exist)">Getback</a></i> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Little_Brother_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Little Brother (band) (page does not exist)">Little Brother</a>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Gangster_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Gangster (album) (page does not exist)">American Gangster</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Graduation_(album)" title="Graduation (album)">Graduation</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">Kanye West</a> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Insomniac_(Enrique_Iglesias_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Insomniac (Enrique Iglesias album) (page does not exist)">Insomniac</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Iglesias" title="Enrique Iglesias">Enrique Iglesias</a>. "Make it Rain", a <a href="/wiki/Scott_Storch" title="Scott Storch">Scott Storch</a> production that peaked at number 13 on the Hot 100 and number two on the Hot Rap Tracks chart,<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> was nominated for the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Rap_Performance_by_a_Duo_or_Group" title="Grammy Award for Best Rap Performance by a Duo or Group">Grammy Award for Best Rap Performance by a Duo or Group</a> for 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Vibe</i> magazine ranked a list of 77 of Lil Wayne's songs from 2007 and ranked his verse in DJ Khaled's "We Takin Over" as his best of 2007, with "Dough Is What I Got" (a freestyle over the beat of Jay-Z's "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Show_Me_What_You_Got&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Show Me What You Got (page does not exist)">Show Me What You Got</a>") from <i>Da Drought 3</i> the second song.<sup id="cite_ref-Vibe_Nov_2007_12-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vibe_Nov_2007-12">[12]</a></sup> At the end of 2007, an MTV poll selected Lil Wayne as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=MTV%27s_Annual_Hottest_MC_List&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MTV's Annual Hottest MC List (page does not exist)">Hottest MC in the Game</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> <i>The New Yorker</i> magazine ranked him "Rapper of the Year",<sup id="cite_ref-new_yorker_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-new_yorker-9">[9]</a></sup> and <i>GQ</i> magazine named him "Workaholic of the Year".<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> In 2008 he was named "Best MC" by <i>Rolling Stone</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Best_MC_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Best_MC-5">[5]</a></sup> Another article, built around Lil Wayne's 2007 mixtape work, cites his creative practice as an example of post performance creative practice.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2008.E2.80.9310:_Tha_Carter_III.2C_We_Are_Young_Money.2C_and_Rebirth">2008–10: <i>Tha Carter III</i>, <i>We Are Young Money</i>, and <i>Rebirth</i></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lil_Wayne_(cropped).jpg" title="File:Lil Wayne (cropped).jpg">File:Lil Wayne (cropped).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Lil Wayne performing in concert at <a href="/wiki/Rogers_Arena" title="Rogers Arena">Rogers Arena</a> in Vancouver B.C., January 2009</div></div></div>
<p>In 2007, Lil Wayne stated that he would reunite with Hot Boys, with plans to release an album after B.G.'s solo album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Too_Hood_to_Be_Hollywood&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Too Hood to Be Hollywood (page does not exist)">Too Hood to Be Hollywood</a></i> was completed.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Carter_III&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Carter III (page does not exist)">Tha Carter III</a></i> was originally scheduled to be released in 2007, though it was delayed after several recordings were leaked and distributed through mixtapes, including "The Drought Is Over Pt. 2" and "The Drought Is Over Pt. 4". Lil Wayne initially planned to release <i>The Leak</i>, a separate album with leaked songs and four additional tracks, on December 18, 2007, with <i>Tha Carter III</i> delayed to March 18, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-carterrelease_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-carterrelease-34">[34]</a></sup> Instead, <i>The Leak</i> became an <a href="/wiki/Extended_play" title="Extended play">EP</a> with five songs and was released digitally on December 25, 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Tha Carter III</i> was released on June 10, 2008, with first-week sales of over 1 million copies, the first to do so since <a href="/wiki/50_Cent" title="50 Cent">50 Cent</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_Massacre" title="The Massacre">The Massacre</a></i> (2005).<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> The first single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Lollipop_(Lil_Wayne_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lollipop (Lil Wayne song) (page does not exist)">Lollipop</a>", featuring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Steve_%22Static%22_Garrett&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Steve &quot;Static&quot; Garrett (page does not exist)">Static Major</a>, became the rapper's most successful song at the time, topping the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">Billboard Hot 100</a> and becoming his first top 10 single as a solo artist and his first number one on the chart. The third single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Got_Money&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Got Money (page does not exist)">Got Money</a>", featuring T-Pain, peaked at number 13 on the Billboard 100. The album went on to win four Grammy Awards, including best rap album and best rap song, which he won for "Lollipop".<sup id="cite_ref-Grammy_2009_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Grammy_2009-37">[37]</a></sup> On July 14, 2008, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recording_Industry_Association_of_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recording Industry Association of America (page does not exist)">Recording Industry Association of America</a> certified <i>Tha Carter III</i> two times platinum.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> In October 2008, Lil Wayne announced plans to MTV News to re-release the album with new tracks, including a duet with <a href="/wiki/Ludacris" title="Ludacris">Ludacris</a> and remixes of "A Milli".<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lil Wayne also appeared on R&amp;B singles "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Girls_Around_the_World&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Girls Around the World (page does not exist)">Girls Around the World</a>" by Lloyd, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Love_In_This_Club&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Love In This Club (page does not exist)">Love In This Club, Part II</a>" by <a href="/wiki/Usher_(entertainer)" title="Usher (entertainer)">Usher</a>, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Official_Girl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Official Girl (page does not exist)">Official Girl</a>" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cassie_(singer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cassie (singer) (page does not exist)">Cassie</a>, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=I%27m_So_Paid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I'm So Paid (page does not exist)">I'm So Paid</a>" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Akon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Akon (page does not exist)">Akon</a>, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Turnin%27_Me_On&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turnin' Me On (page does not exist)">Turnin' Me On</a>" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Keri_Hilson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Keri Hilson (page does not exist)">Keri Hilson</a>, and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Can%27t_Believe_It&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Can't Believe It (page does not exist)">Can't Believe It</a>" by T-Pain; rap singles "<a href="/w/index.php?title=My_Life_(The_Game_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="My Life (The Game song) (page does not exist)">My Life</a>" by <a href="/wiki/The_Game_(rapper)" title="The Game (rapper)">The Game</a>, "Shawty Say" by <a href="/wiki/David_Banner" title="David Banner">David Banner</a>, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Swagga_Like_Us&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swagga Like Us (page does not exist)">Swagga Like Us</a>" by <a href="/wiki/T.I." title="T.I.">T.I.</a>, "Cutty Buddy" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mike_Jones_(rapper)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mike Jones (rapper) (page does not exist)">Mike Jones</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=All_My_Life_(In_the_Ghetto)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="All My Life (In the Ghetto) (page does not exist)">All My Life (In the Ghetto)</a> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jay_Rock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jay Rock (page does not exist)">Jay Rock</a> and the remix to "Certified" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Glasses_Malone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Glasses Malone (page does not exist)">Glasses Malone</a>; and pop single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Let_It_Rock_(Kevin_Rudolf_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Let It Rock (Kevin Rudolf song) (page does not exist)">Let It Rock</a>" by new <a href="/wiki/Cash_Money_Records" title="Cash Money Records">Cash Money</a> artist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kevin_Rudolf&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kevin Rudolf (page does not exist)">Kevin Rudolf</a>.
</p><p>In 2008, Lil Wayne performed at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Voodoo_Experience&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Voodoo Experience (page does not exist)">Voodoo Experience</a> in October in New Orleans, which was described by Jonathan Cohen of <i>Billboard</i> as his biggest hometown headlining set of his career.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> He also performed at the <a href="/wiki/Virgin_Mobile" title="Virgin Mobile">Virgin Mobile Music Fest</a> with <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">Kanye West</a>, where they performed the remix of "Lollipop" and lip-synced to <a href="/wiki/Whitney_Houston" title="Whitney Houston">Whitney Houston</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/I_Will_Always_Love_You" title="I Will Always Love You">I Will Always Love You</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> Lil Wayne also performed at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_MTV_Video_Music_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 MTV Video Music Awards (page does not exist)">2008 MTV Video Music Awards</a> with <a href="/wiki/Kid_Rock" title="Kid Rock">Kid Rock</a> ("<a href="/w/index.php?title=All_Summer_Long_(Kid_Rock_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="All Summer Long (Kid Rock song) (page does not exist)">All Summer Long</a>"), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leona_Lewis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leona Lewis (page does not exist)">Leona Lewis</a> ("DontGetIt (Misunderstood)") and <a href="/w/index.php?title=T-Pain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="T-Pain (page does not exist)">T-Pain</a> ("<a href="/w/index.php?title=Got_Money&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Got Money (page does not exist)">Got Money</a>") and performed "Lollipop" and "Got Money" on the season premiere of <i><a href="/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> He later performed at the <a href="/wiki/Homecoming" title="Homecoming">homecoming</a> rally at <a href="/wiki/Vanderbilt_University" title="Vanderbilt University">Vanderbilt University</a><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> and the 2008 <a href="/w/index.php?title=BET_Hip_Hop_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BET Hip Hop Awards (page does not exist)">BET Hip Hop Awards</a>, where he received 12 nominations.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> He won eight awards at the BET Hip Hop Awards, one of which included the "MVP" title.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> After <a href="/w/index.php?title=M.I.A._(artist)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="M.I.A. (artist) (page does not exist)">M.I.A.</a> dropped out of performing on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am_Music_Tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am Music Tour (page does not exist)">I Am Music Tour</a> due to her pregnancy, <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a> performed "Mr. Carter" with Lil Wayne at select shows.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following <i>Tha Carter III'</i>s achievement of selling over 3 million copies, becoming 2008's best-selling record, Wayne re-signed with <a href="/wiki/Cash_Money_Records" title="Cash Money Records">Cash Money Records</a> for a multi-album deal.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
On November 11, 2008, Wayne became the first hip-hop act to perform at the <a href="/wiki/Country_Music_Association_Awards" title="Country Music Association Awards">Country Music Association Awards</a>, playing "<a href="/w/index.php?title=All_Summer_Long_(Kid_Rock_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="All Summer Long (Kid Rock song) (page does not exist)">All Summer Long</a>" alongside <a href="/wiki/Kid_Rock" title="Kid Rock">Kid Rock</a>, in which Wayne inaudibly strummed guitar strings alongside the guitarist in Kid Rock's band.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> Shortly after, Wayne was nominated for eight <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammys</a> – the most for any artist nominated that year.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> He was then named the first MTV Man of the Year at the end of 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> He won the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Rap_Solo_Performance" title="Grammy Award for Best Rap Solo Performance">Grammy Award for Best Rap Solo Performance</a> for "<a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Milli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Milli (page does not exist)">A Milli</a>", <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_for_Best_Rap_Performance_By_A_Duo_Or_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grammy Award for Best Rap Performance By A Duo Or Group (page does not exist)">Best Rap Performance by a Duo or Group</a> for his appearance in <a href="/wiki/T.I." title="T.I.">T.I.</a>'s single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Swagga_Like_Us&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swagga Like Us (page does not exist)">Swagga Like Us</a>", and <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Rap_Song" title="Grammy Award for Best Rap Song">Best Rap Song</a> for "Lollipop". <i>Tha Carter III</i> won the award for <a href="/wiki/Best_Rap_Album" title="Best Rap Album" class="mw-redirect">Best Rap Album</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Grammy_2009_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Grammy_2009-37">[37]</a></sup> MTV News listed Lil Wayne number two on their 2009 list of the Hottest MCs In The Game.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 6, 2009, Lil Wayne was a guest debater against <a href="/wiki/Skip_Bayless" title="Skip Bayless">Skip Bayless</a> on the "1st &amp; 10" segment of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=ESPN_First_Take&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ESPN First Take (page does not exist)">ESPN First Take</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> On February 10, 2009, he appeared on ESPN's <a href="/wiki/Around_the_Horn" title="Around the Horn">Around the Horn</a> and beat out veterans <a href="/w/index.php?title=Woody_Paige&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Woody Paige (page does not exist)">Woody Paige</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jay_Mariotti&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jay Mariotti (page does not exist)">Jay Mariotti</a> and fellow New Orleanian <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Smith_(sports_reporter)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Smith (sports reporter) (page does not exist)">Michael Smith</a> to win that show's episode.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> Prior to the 2009 Grammy Awards, Wayne was featured in an interview with <a href="/wiki/Katie_Couric" title="Katie Couric">Katie Couric</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Couric_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Couric-7">[7]</a></sup> On February 7, 2009, he presented the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Top_Ten_list_(David_Letterman)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Top Ten list (David Letterman) (page does not exist)">Top Ten List</a> on CBS's <i><a href="/wiki/Late_Show_with_David_Letterman" title="Late Show with David Letterman">Late Show with David Letterman</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> On April 24, 2009, he appeared on <i><a href="/wiki/The_View_(U.S._TV_series)" title="The View (U.S. TV series)">The View</a></i>, discussing his GED and addictions.<sup id="cite_ref-The_View_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_View-55">[55]</a></sup> In September 2009, Wayne was profiled in an episode of <a href="/wiki/VH1" title="VH1">VH1</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Behind_the_Music" title="Behind the Music">Behind the Music</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> and was a presenter of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_MTV_Movie_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 MTV Movie Awards (page does not exist)">2009 MTV Movie Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> In film, Wayne produced and composed music for and starred in the direct-to-video film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hurricane_Season_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hurricane Season (film) (page does not exist)">Hurricane Season</a></i>. A documentary of Lil Wayne titled <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Carter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Carter (page does not exist)">The Carter</a></i> was released at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sundance_Film_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sundance Film Festival (page does not exist)">Sundance Film Festival</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>On December 23, 2009, Wayne released a collaboration album with Young Money, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Are_Young_Money&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Are Young Money (page does not exist)">We Are Young Money</a></i>, with its lead single being "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Every_Girl_(Young_Money_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Every Girl (Young Money song) (page does not exist)">Every Girl</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> The second single was "<a href="/w/index.php?title=BedRock_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BedRock (song) (page does not exist)">BedRock</a>", featuring <a href="/wiki/Lloyd_(singer)" title="Lloyd (singer)">Lloyd</a>, with the third being "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Roger_That_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roger That (song) (page does not exist)">Roger That</a>". On May 24, 2010, the album was certified gold by the RIAA with over 500,000 copies sold.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> Wayne is featured on the song, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Revolver_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Revolver (song) (page does not exist)">Revolver</a>", with <a href="/wiki/Madonna_(entertainer)" title="Madonna (entertainer)">Madonna</a> for her greatest hits album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Celebration_(Madonna_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Celebration (Madonna album) (page does not exist)">Celebration</a></i> (2009). He was also featured on a <a href="/wiki/Weezer" title="Weezer">Weezer</a> song, "Can't Stop Partying", on <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Raditude&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raditude (page does not exist)">Raditude</a></i> (2009).<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> In late 2008, Wayne announced plans to reissue <i>Tha Carter III</i> with leftover recordings, and was to be titled <i>Rebirth</i>. Originally scheduled to be released on April 7, 2009 before being delayed several times, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rebirth_(Lil_Wayne_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rebirth (Lil Wayne album) (page does not exist)">Rebirth</a></i> instead became his debut rock album, released on April 7, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-Reid_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reid-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p><p>To support its release and that of <i>We Are Young Money</i>, he was featured on the cover of <i>Rolling Stone</i><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> and headlined the 'Young Money Presents: America's Most Wanted Music Festival', a United States and Canada–only concert tour which began on July 29, 2009. "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Prom_Queen_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prom Queen (song) (page does not exist)">Prom Queen</a>", the first official single, debuted on January 27, 2009 immediately after a live Internet broadcast on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ustream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ustream (page does not exist)">Ustream</a><sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> of his concert in San Diego.<sup id="cite_ref-mtvrebirth_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mtvrebirth-65">[65]</a></sup> It peaked at number 15 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a> charts. On December 3, 2009, the second single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=On_Fire_(Lil_Wayne_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="On Fire (Lil Wayne song) (page does not exist)">On Fire</a>", produced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cool_%26_Dre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cool &amp; Dre (page does not exist)">Cool &amp; Dre</a><sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-66">[66]</a></sup> "On Fire" peaked at number 33 on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 charts. "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Drop_the_World&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drop the World (page does not exist)">Drop the World</a>", which features <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eminem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eminem (page does not exist)">Eminem</a>, was the third single from the album.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2010.E2.80.9311:_I_Am_Not_a_Human_Being_and_Tha_Carter_IV">2010–11: <i>I Am Not a Human Being</i> and <i>Tha Carter IV</i></span></h3>
<p>In an interview on MTV's Mixtape Monday, Wayne asserted the possibility of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Carter_IV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Carter IV (page does not exist)">Tha Carter IV</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> later announcing that it would be released in 2009 before the holiday season.<sup id="cite_ref-2009rebirthc4_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2009rebirthc4-68">[68]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Birdman_(rapper)" title="Birdman (rapper)">Birdman</a> had previously stated that <i>Tha Carter IV</i> would be packaged with <i>Rebirth</i> as a double disc album.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> However, Wayne denied this idea saying that "<i>Tha Carter IV</i> deserves <i>Tha Carter IV</i>", adding that <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Are_Young_Money&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Are Young Money (page does not exist)">We Are Young Money</a></i> may be packaged with <i>Rebirth</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> However, both albums were released separately.
</p><p>Originally thought to be an <a href="/wiki/Extended_play" title="Extended play">EP</a>, Lil Wayne released his tenth album, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am_Not_a_Human_Being&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am Not a Human Being (page does not exist)">I Am Not a Human Being</a></i>, on his 28th birthday, September 27, 2010. The album has sold over 953,000 copies in the U.S.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> and has spawned successful single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Right_Above_It&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Right Above It (page does not exist)">Right Above It</a>", which peaked at No. 6 on the Billboard Hot 100. <i>Tha Carter IV</i> was later delayed into 2011, after Lil Wayne began recording from scratch after his release from prison.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> He described his first song sine his release as "a 2010 version of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Milli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Milli (page does not exist)">A Milli</a></i> on steroids." The album's lead single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=6_Foot_7_Foot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="6 Foot 7 Foot (page does not exist)">6 Foot 7 Foot</a>" featuring Cory Gunz, was released on December 15, 2010 and made available for digital download on <a href="/wiki/ITunes" title="ITunes">iTunes</a> on December 16, 2010. The song is produced by Bangladesh, who also produced "A Milli".<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 8, 2011, Lil Wayne released another song, "We Back Soon", produced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=StreetRunner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="StreetRunner (page does not exist)">StreetRunner</a>, though it was not included on the official track listing of <i>Tha Carter IV</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-We_Back_Soon_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-We_Back_Soon-75">[75]</a></sup> The second single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=John_(Lil_Wayne_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John (Lil Wayne song) (page does not exist)">John</a>", was released on March 24, 2011, which features <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rick_Ross&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rick Ross (page does not exist)">Rick Ross</a> and is produced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Polow_Da_Don&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Polow Da Don (page does not exist)">Polow Da Don</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> The album's artwork was unveiled on April 20, 2011. The album was originally scheduled to be released on May 16, 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> but <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mack_Maine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mack Maine (page does not exist)">Mack Maine</a> had confirmed its delay to June 21. On May 26, 2011, the third single, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=How_to_Love&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="How to Love (page does not exist)">How to Love</a>", was released. A song called "Dear Anne <i>(Stan Part 2)</i>" was released in June. Lil Wayne said the song was a throwaway track from <i>Tha Carter III</i> and was originally supposed to be on <i>Tha Carter IV</i>, but decided not to put it on there because of its age. Lil Wayne said that he liked the beat, but not the lyrics, and was thinking about revamping the song.
</p><p>In July 2011, Lil Wayne confirmed in an interview with MTV that <i>Tha Carter IV</i> was finished, and was released on August 29, 2011. For preparation for <i>Tha Carter IV</i>, Lil Wayne released a mixtape, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sorry_4_the_Wait&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sorry 4 the Wait (page does not exist)">Sorry 4 the Wait</a></i>, with all the beats coming from other artist's songa, similar to his "<a href="/w/index.php?title=No_Ceilings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="No Ceilings (page does not exist)">No Ceilings</a>" mixtape. <i>Tha Carter IV</i> debuted at No. 1 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200">Billboard 200</a>, with first-week sales of 964,000 copies, making it Lil Wayne's third chart topping album of his career. On January 8, 2012, According to <a href="/wiki/Nielsen_SoundScan" title="Nielsen SoundScan">Nielsen SoundScan</a> was elected the seventh artist (second male artist) all-time best-selling <a href="/wiki/Music_download" title="Music download">tracks digital</a> with 36,788,000 million to the end of 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2012.E2.80.93present:_I_Am_Not_A_Human_Being_II">2012–present: <i>I Am Not A Human Being II</i></span></h3>
<p>In October 2011, it was reported that Lil Wayne was working on sequels to <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am_Not_a_Human_Being&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am Not a Human Being (page does not exist)">I Am Not a Human Being</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rebirth_(Lil_Wayne_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rebirth (Lil Wayne album) (page does not exist)">Rebirth</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> In January 2012, Birdman announced that he and Wayne had finished recording <i>Like Father, Like Son 2</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-80">[80]</a></sup> On November 22, 2012, he announced that <i>Tha Carter V</i> would be his final album.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p><p>After numerous delays, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am_Not_a_Human_Being_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am Not a Human Being II (page does not exist)">I Am Not a Human Being II</a></i> was released on March 26, 2013 debuting at #2 on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_200" title="Billboard 200">Billboard 200</a> selling 217,000 copies in its first week;<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> "<a href="/w/index.php?title=My_Homies_Still&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="My Homies Still (page does not exist)">My Homies Still</a>", "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Love_Me_(Lil_Wayne_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Love Me (Lil Wayne song) (page does not exist)">Love Me</a>", and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=No_Worries_(Lil_Wayne_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="No Worries (Lil Wayne song) (page does not exist)">No Worries</a>" were released as singles prior to its release. The album was met with generally mixed reviews, with most critics noticing the declining quality of his releases. Lil Wayne toured North America with <a href="/w/index.php?title=2_Chainz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2 Chainz (page does not exist)">2 Chainz</a> and <a href="/wiki/T.I." title="T.I.">T.I.</a> on the second Americas Most Wanted Festivil.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p><p>On May 3, 2013, <a href="/wiki/Pepsi" title="Pepsi">Pepsi</a> dropped Lil Wayne, who was a spokesperson for <a href="/wiki/Mountain_Dew" title="Mountain Dew">Mountain Dew</a>, due to offensive lyrics about about <a href="/w/index.php?title=Civil_rights_movement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Civil rights movement (page does not exist)">civil-rights</a> icon <a href="/wiki/Emmett_Till" title="Emmett Till">Emmett Till</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>On September 1, 2013, Lil Wayne released the fifth instalment of the "Dedication" mixtape series, with <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dedication_5&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dedication 5 (page does not exist)">Dedication 5</a></i>. The mixtape featured 29 tracks, with guest appearances from <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Weeknd&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Weeknd (page does not exist)">The Weeknd</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chance_The_Rapper&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chance The Rapper (page does not exist)">Chance The Rapper</a>, Jae Millz, Birdman, T.I., <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vado&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vado (page does not exist)">Vado</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kidd_Kidd&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kidd Kidd (page does not exist)">Kidd Kidd</a>, and 2 Chainz among other members of Young Money.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Future_projects">Future projects</span></h3>
<p>Lil Wayne has announced several possible upcoming projects, including a collaborative album entitled <i>I Can't Feel My Face</i> with Harlem-based rapper <a href="/wiki/Juelz_Santana" title="Juelz Santana">Juelz Santana</a>, that has been in production for several years.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cant_feel_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cant_feel-87">[87]</a></sup> On June 19, 2008, Lil Wayne and <a href="/w/index.php?title=T-Pain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="T-Pain (page does not exist)">T-Pain</a> formed a duo called T-Wayne<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> with plans to release an album however those plans have died down.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> According to an interview with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drake_(entertainer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drake (entertainer) (page does not exist)">Drake</a>, in the December 2011 issue of <a href="/wiki/XXL_(magazine)" title="XXL (magazine)">XXL</a>, plans for an upcoming album with Lil Wayne had been scrapped for the time being because of the <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">Kanye West</a> collaboration <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Watch_the_Throne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Watch the Throne (page does not exist)">Watch the Throne</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Drake_album_scrapped_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Drake_album_scrapped-90">[90]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hiphopdx.com_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hiphopdx.com-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p><p>In late 2011, it was announced by Mack Maine, that Lil Wayne and <a href="/wiki/Juelz_Santana" title="Juelz Santana">Juelz Santana</a> have gone back to working on their collaborative album <i>I Can't Feel My Face</i>, which had been delayed for a few years due to "label politics".<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> In April 2012, on the premiere of <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV</a>’s Hip Hop POV, Wayne sat down with Amanda Seales and spoke briefly about an album he put together titled <i>Devol</i> (loved, backwards), an album full of “love songs” that he wrote during his imprisonment at <a href="/wiki/Rikers_Island" title="Rikers Island">Rikers Island</a>. In May 2013 he has confirmed the album will still be released.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> He also announced that a new <a href="/wiki/Big_Tymers" title="Big Tymers">Big Tymers</a> album would be released, which would result in Drake and himself being added to the group. Wayne has indicated that some of these projects will be released prior to his final album, which will be <i>Tha Carter V</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Retirement">Retirement</span></h3>
<p>On March 29, 2011, in an interview with <a href="/wiki/WQHT" title="WQHT">Hot 97</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Angie_Martinez" title="Angie Martinez">Angie Martinez</a>, Lil Wayne announced that he would retire at age 35; saying "I have four kids," and that "I would feel selfish still going to the studio when it's such a vital point in their lives."<sup id="cite_ref-Lil_Wayne_on_the_Angie_Martinez_show_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lil_Wayne_on_the_Angie_Martinez_show-97">[97]</a></sup> He said in November 2012 that <i>Tha Carter V</i> will be his last album as he wanted to go into other interests.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Philanthropy">Philanthropy</span></h2>
<p>On February 19, 2008, Lil Wayne and Cortez Bryant revisited their alma mater McMain Secondary School to get students to design an invitation to the gala introducing Lil Wayne's nonprofit One Family Foundation.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> The website Change.org states: "The mission of One Family Foundation, Inc. is to empower urban youth by engaging them in opportunities to cultivate their talents and skills, educating them to become productive and economically self-sufficient, and motivating them to dream beyond their circumstances."<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Relationships_and_children">Relationships and children</span></h3>
<p>Lil Wayne has four children. His first child, daughter Reginae, was born when he was 15,{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} to his high school sweetheart <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antonia_%22Toya%22_Carter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antonia &quot;Toya&quot; Carter (page does not exist)">Antonia "Toya" Carter</a> (née Johnson). They married on Valentine's Day 2004 and divorced in 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> Internet rumors started circulating in August 2008 that Wayne's daughter had died in a car crash, which however he quickly cleared up as false saying "Please allow me to dispel any rumors or speculations and report that my daughter is alive, healthy and surrounded by family who care and love her dearly. The rumors are completely false and unfounded; neither Reginae nor any other member of my family has been involved in any car accident."<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>His second child, Dwayne III, was born on October 22, 2008 at <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Christ_Hospital&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Christ Hospital (page does not exist)">The Christ Hospital</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cincinnati&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cincinnati (page does not exist)">Cincinnati</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> His third child, Cameron Carter, was born to actress <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lauren_London&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lauren London (page does not exist)">Lauren London</a> on September 9, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> His fourth child, Neal, was born on November 30, 2009 to singer <a href="/wiki/Nivea_(singer)" title="Nivea (singer)">Nivea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> He also got rapper <a href="/wiki/Trina" title="Trina">Trina</a> pregnant but she suffered a miscarriage.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Beliefs_and_interests">Beliefs and interests</span></h3>
<p>In an interview with <i><a href="/wiki/Blender_(magazine)" title="Blender (magazine)">Blender</a></i> magazine, Lil Wayne revealed one of his favorite bands from childhood to be rock group <a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(band)" title="Nirvana (band)">Nirvana</a>, and cites them as a major influence in his music.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>Wayne got his first tattoo at age 14 of his dad's name and his second was "Cash Money" across his stomach.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> His tattoos have grown to include a <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a> verse on his leg, "I Am Music" on his forehead and teardrops on his cheeks among many others. His most recent one is "Baked" on his forehead stylized as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baker_Skateboards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baker Skateboards (page does not exist)">Baker Skateboards</a> logo.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lil Wayne identifies as a <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" title="Roman Catholic" class="mw-redirect">Roman Catholic</a><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> and reads the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a> regularly.<sup id="cite_ref-New_York_Times_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-New_York_Times-112">[112]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Weezy_Thanx_You_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weezy_Thanx_You-113">[113]</a></sup> While playing in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Newark_Symphony_Hall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Newark Symphony Hall (page does not exist)">Newark Symphony Hall</a>, Lil Wayne professed his belief "in God and His son, Jesus."<sup id="cite_ref-New_York_Times_112-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-New_York_Times-112">[112]</a></sup> During his 2011 tour in Australia with Eminem, before beginning his bracket he proclaimed his belief in God.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup>
</p><p>After earning his <a href="/w/index.php?title=GED&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="GED (page does not exist)">GED</a>, Wayne enrolled at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Houston" title="University of Houston">University of Houston</a> in January 2005. He dropped out in the same year due to his conflicting schedule.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> He also revealed on <i><a href="/wiki/The_View_(U.S._TV_series)" title="The View (U.S. TV series)">The View</a></i> that he switched to the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Phoenix" title="University of Phoenix">University of Phoenix</a> and majored in psychology taking <a href="/w/index.php?title=Online_courses&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Online courses (page does not exist)">online courses</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_View_55-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_View-55">[55]</a></sup> An article in <i>Urb</i> magazine in March 2007 asserted that Wayne had been earning high grades at Houston.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup>
</p><p>On September 24, 2008, Lil Wayne published his first blog for <a href="/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a> in their issue, <i><a href="/wiki/ESPN_The_Magazine" title="ESPN The Magazine">ESPN The Magazine</a></i>. Wayne revealed he was a fan of tennis, the <a href="/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers" title="Green Bay Packers">Green Bay Packers</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Boston_Bruins" title="Boston Bruins">Boston Bruins</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers" title="Los Angeles Lakers">Los Angeles Lakers</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Boston_Red_Sox" title="Boston Red Sox">Boston Red Sox</a>.
