To commemorate the <a href="/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers" title="Green Bay Packers">Packers'</a> making it to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_XLV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Super Bowl XLV (page does not exist)">Super Bowl XLV</a>, he spoofed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wiz_Khalifa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wiz Khalifa (page does not exist)">Wiz Khalifa</a>'s hit song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Black_and_Yellow&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Black and Yellow (page does not exist)">Black and Yellow</a>" (which were the colors of the Packers' opponents, the <a href="/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers" title="Pittsburgh Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a>) in a song titled "Green and Yellow".<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> Wayne has continued writing for ESPN, notably reporting at the ESPN <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl" title="Super Bowl">Super Bowl</a> party.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> Lil Wayne made his debut on ESPN's daily sports round table show <i>Around The Horn</i> on February 10, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>Wayne received criticism after a video released by TMZ showed him apparently stepping on the American flag. Wayne later explained that "It was never my intention to desecrate the flag of the United States," and that he was shooting a video for a song on his upcoming album, "God Bless Amerika." He claims the purpose of the flag was to "show that 'behind the American Flag was the Hoods of America'." <sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_issues">Health issues</span></h3>
<p>On October 25, 2012, Lil Wayne's private jet, bound for <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, made an <a href="/wiki/Emergency_landing" title="Emergency landing">emergency landing</a> in <a href="/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">Texas</a> due to an in-flight medical episode. Lil Wayne was transferred to a local hospital upon arrival.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=TMZ_(website)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TMZ (website) (page does not exist)">TMZ</a> and other media sources claimed that Lil Wayne had suffered a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seizure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seizure (page does not exist)">seizure</a> aboard the plane.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> His publicist denied this, claiming that he was in fact treated for "a severe migraine and dehydration."<sup id="cite_ref-spin2012_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-spin2012-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>The following day, while flying from Texas to Los Angeles, Lil Wayne's private jet was reportedly again forced to make an emergency landing, this time in <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>, after Lil Wayne suffered a second seizure and required further hospitalization.<sup id="cite_ref-spin2012_123-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-spin2012-123">[123]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> His representative claimed that the reports of Lil Wayne's condition had been exaggerated, and that he was resting at his Louisiana home.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> In a November 2012 interview with <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV</a>, Lil Wayne revealed that he was taking seizure medication, on doctors' orders, due to the aforementioned incidents.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 14, 2013, TMZ reported that Lil Wayne had been treated at <a href="/wiki/Cedars-Sinai_Medical_Center" title="Cedars-Sinai Medical Center">Cedars-Sinai Medical Center</a> in Los Angeles on the evening of March 12, after suffering seizures while on a music video set with Young Money rapper <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nicki_Minaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nicki Minaj (page does not exist)">Nicki Minaj</a>. He was reportedly released in the early hours of March 13.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> On March 15, TMZ published a second story, claiming that hours after his release on March 13, Lil Wayne was found unconscious after experiencing further seizures, and was brought back to Cedars-Sinai, where he was admitted to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Intensive_Care_Unit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Intensive Care Unit (page does not exist)">Intensive Care Unit</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Critical_condition&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Critical condition (page does not exist)">critical condition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tmz2013march_15_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tmz2013march_15-129">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> The article alleged the latest seizures were found to be linked to high amounts of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Codeine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Codeine (page does not exist)">codeine</a> in Lil Wayne's system, possibly due to binging on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Purple_drank&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Purple drank (page does not exist)">purple drank</a> after his initial hospital release.<sup id="cite_ref-tmz2013march_15_129-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tmz2013march_15-129">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-billlboardmarch2013_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billlboardmarch2013-131">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> Multiple celebrities, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drake_(entertainer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drake (entertainer) (page does not exist)">Drake</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Birdman_(entertainer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Birdman (entertainer) (page does not exist)">Birdman</a>, were photographed on March 15 and 16 visiting Lil Wayne at Cedars-Sinai.<sup id="cite_ref-billlboardmarch2013_131-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-billlboardmarch2013-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several members of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Young_Money_Entertainment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Young Money Entertainment (page does not exist)">Young Money Entertainment</a>, including president <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mack_Maine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mack Maine (page does not exist)">Mack Maine</a>, criticized media reports on Lil Wayne's hospitalization, particularly those of TMZ, alleging that they exaggerated the severity of his condition and falsely implied that he was on his <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/deathbed" class="extiw" title="wikt:deathbed">deathbed</a> (such as by claiming that he was in a medically <a href="/wiki/Induced_coma" title="Induced coma">induced coma</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> triggering what the <i><a href="/wiki/Washington_Post" title="Washington Post" class="mw-redirect">Washington Post</a></i> called "the most overheated celebrity deathwatch in recent years."<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> In separate interviews on March 18, Mack Maine and Birdman disputed TMZ's reports, and stated that in fact there were not multiple seizures or multiple hospital visits. They explained that after Lil Wayne began seizing on the way to the music video shoot on March 12, an ambulance was called and he was transported to the hospital, where he was admitted and remained continuously thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>  They also refuted the claims that Lil Wayne's seizures are drug-induced, noting that they are an ongoing problem for which doctors have been unable to identify a cause.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lil Wayne was released from the hospital late on March 18, following a six-day stay.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> Lil Wayne addressed his condition via a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vlog&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vlog (page does not exist)">vlog</a>, on March 21 saying he was more than good.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> In a March 28 interview with <a href="/w/index.php?title=DJ_Felli_Fel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DJ Felli Fel (page does not exist)">DJ Felli Fel</a> of <a href="/wiki/Power_106" title="Power 106" class="mw-redirect">Power 106</a> in Los Angeles, Wayne said that he suffers from <a href="/wiki/Epilepsy" title="Epilepsy">epilepsy</a>, a neurological condition which is noted by seizures. He would say "This isn't my first, second, third, fourth, fifth, sixth or seventh seizure. I've had a bunch of seizures. Y'all just never hear about them. But this time, it got real bad because I had three of them in a row."<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_references_by_Barack_Obama">Public references by Barack Obama</span></h3>
<p>Lil Wayne has been referenced in public speeches by President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> on at least two occasions, in mixed contexts. Speaking to a largely African-American audience during a <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2008#General_election_campaign" title="United States presidential election, 2008">general election campaign</a> <a href="/wiki/Town_hall_meeting" title="Town hall meeting">town hall speech</a> in <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">Georgia</a>, then-<a href="/wiki/United_States_Senator" title="United States Senator" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Senator</a> Obama exhorted children to stay in school and achieve their dreams through education and perseverance instead of hoping for shortcuts to fame and riches as professional athletes and entertainers via the fields of sports and entertainment, stating: "You are probably not that good a rapper. Maybe you are the next Lil Wayne, but probably not, in which case you need to stay in school."<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup>
</p>
After assuming the Presidency, Obama later echoed this theme of personal and familial responsibility and the difficulty of achieving Lil Wayne's professional and financial success—during an address to a meeting commemorating the 100th anniversary of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=NAACP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NAACP (page does not exist)">NAACP</a>, telling the audience:<blockquote class="templatequote">They might think they've got a pretty jump shot or a pretty good flow, but our kids can’t all aspire to be <a href="/wiki/LeBron_James" title="LeBron James">LeBron</a> or Lil Wayne. I want them aspiring to be scientists and engineers, doctors and teachers, not just ballers and rappers. I want them aspiring to be a <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">Supreme Court justice</a>. I want them aspiring to be President of the United States of America.<sup id="cite_ref-Obama_NAACP_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Obama_NAACP-141">[141]</a></sup>
</blockquote>
<p>Obama has also noted that the music on his iPod includes Lil Wayne:
</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">My rap palate has greatly improved. Jay-Z used to be sort of what predominated, but now I've got a little <a href="/wiki/Nas" title="Nas">Nas</a> and a little Lil Wayne and some other stuff.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup>
</blockquote>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_issues">Legal issues</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arrests_and_incarceration">Arrests and incarceration</span></h3>
<p>On July 22, 2007, Lil Wayne was arrested in New York City following a performance at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beacon_Theatre_(New_York_City)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beacon Theatre (New York City) (page does not exist)">Beacon Theatre</a>; the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department" title="New York City Police Department">New York City Police Department</a> discovered Lil Wayne and another man smoking <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marijuana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marijuana (page does not exist)">marijuana</a> near a tour bus. After taking Lil Wayne into custody, police discovered a .40 caliber pistol on his person. The gun, which was registered to his manager, was in a bag located near the rapper.<sup id="cite_ref-sentence_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sentence-143">[143]</a></sup> He was charged with criminal possession of a weapon and marijuana.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>On October 22, 2009, Lil Wayne pleaded guilty to attempted criminal possession of a weapon. He was due for sentencing in February 2010 and was expected to receive a one-year county jail sentence,<sup id="cite_ref-guiltyplea_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guiltyplea-146">[146]</a></sup> but on February 9, 2010, Lil Wayne's attorney announced that the sentencing was delayed until March 2 due to dental surgery,<sup id="cite_ref-delay_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-delay-147">[147]</a></sup> which was performed on February 16. The surgery included eight root canals, the replacement of several tooth implants, as well as the addition of a few new implants and work on his remaining original teeth.<sup id="cite_ref-surgery_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-surgery-148">[148]</a></sup> On March 2, 2010, sentencing was postponed again when the courthouse reported a fire in the basement.<sup id="cite_ref-CourthouseFire_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CourthouseFire-149">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 8, 2010, Lil Wayne was sentenced to a year in prison, which he served in <a href="/wiki/Rikers_Island" title="Rikers Island">Rikers Island</a>. His lawyer said the rapper expected to be held in protective custody, separated from other prisoners.<sup id="cite_ref-sentenced_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sentenced-150">[150]</a></sup> In May 2010 Wayne was found by Rikers Island correctional staff to be in possession of contraband (an MP3 player, charger, and headphones).<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> In April 2010, Lil Wayne's friends created a website called Weezy Thanx You, which publishes letters written by Wayne in prison.<sup id="cite_ref-Weezy_Thanx_You_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weezy_Thanx_You-113">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Weezy_Thanx_You_Website_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weezy_Thanx_You_Website-152">[152]</a></sup> In the first letter, titled "Gone 'til November", the rapper described his daily routine, saying he works out a lot, and reads <a href="/wiki/The_Bible" title="The Bible" class="mw-redirect">the Bible</a> every day.<sup id="cite_ref-Weezy_Thanx_You_113-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weezy_Thanx_You-113">[113]</a></sup> Wayne was released from Rikers Island prison facility on November 4, 2010 after serving eight months of his year-long sentence.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following a performance at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Qwest_Arena&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Qwest Arena (page does not exist)">Qwest Arena</a> in <a href="/wiki/Boise,_Idaho" title="Boise, Idaho">Boise</a>, Idaho, Lil Wayne was arrested October 5, 2007 on felony fugitive charges after <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">Georgia</a> authorities accused the rapper of possessing a controlled substance.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> The incident was later described as a "mix-up" and the fugitive charges were dropped.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 23, 2008, Lil Wayne was arrested alongside two others. His tour bus was stopped by <a href="/wiki/United_States_Border_Patrol" title="United States Border Patrol">Border Patrol</a> agents near <a href="/wiki/Yuma,_Arizona" title="Yuma, Arizona">Yuma</a>, Arizona. A K-9 Unit recovered <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of marijuana, almost <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of cocaine, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of <a href="/wiki/MDMA" title="MDMA">ecstasy</a>, and $22,000 in cash. Lil Wayne was charged with four felonies: possession of narcotic drug for sale, possession of dangerous drugs, misconduct involving weapons and possession of drug paraphernalia. He was granted permission to travel outside of the state and remain out of custody on the $10,185 bond he posted.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>On May 6, 2008, Wayne returned to court in Arizona to plead not guilty to the charges.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Bench_warrant" title="Bench warrant" class="mw-redirect">bench warrant</a> was issued on March 17, 2010 when Lil Wayne did not show for a final trial management conference.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> However, the rapper was already in prison, serving a year-long sentence in Rikers on weapons charges. On June 22, 2010 Wayne pleaded guilty to the charges. As part of the plea deal he may serve 36 months of probation.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> On June 30, 2010, he was sentenced to 3 years probation.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>On December 18, 2009, Wayne and 11 others were detained at the <a href="/wiki/Falfurrias,_Texas" title="Falfurrias, Texas">Falfurrias</a>, Texas border patrol checkpoint after an unknown amount of marijuana was found on two of his tour buses.<sup id="cite_ref-Falfurrias_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Falfurrias-162">[162]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Lawsuits">Lawsuits</span></h3>
<p>On July 24, 2008, <a href="/wiki/ABKCO_Records" title="ABKCO Records">Abkco Music Inc</a> filed a <a href="/wiki/Lawsuit" title="Lawsuit">lawsuit</a> against Lil Wayne for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Copyright_infringement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Copyright infringement (page does not exist)">copyright infringement</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trademark_infringement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trademark infringement (page does not exist)">unfair competition</a>, specifically referring to <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Carter_III&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Carter III (page does not exist)">Tha Carter III</a>'</i>s track "Playing with Fire".<sup id="cite_ref-abkco_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-abkco-163">[163]</a></sup> In the lawsuit, Abkco claims that the song was obviously derived from <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">The Rolling Stones</a>' "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Play_with_Fire_(The_Rolling_Stones_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Play with Fire (The Rolling Stones song) (page does not exist)">Play with Fire</a>", to which Abkco owns the rights.<sup id="cite_ref-abkco_163-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-abkco-163">[163]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup> Subsequently, "Playing with Fire" was removed from the tracklist of <i>Tha Carter III</i> on all <a href="/w/index.php?title=Online_music_stores&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Online music stores (page does not exist)">online music stores</a> and replaced with the <a href="/wiki/David_Banner" title="David Banner">David Banner</a> produced track, "Pussy Monster".<sup id="cite_ref-iTunespussymonster_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iTunespussymonster-165">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Amazonpussymonster_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Amazonpussymonster-166">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rhapsodypussymonster_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rhapsodypussymonster-167">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 2009, production company RMF Productions filed a $1.3&#160;million lawsuit against Wayne, following a $100,000 advance payment for three shows, all of which were cancelled by the artist.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p>On October 2009, Lil Wayne, <a href="/wiki/Birdman_(rapper)" title="Birdman (rapper)">Birdman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cash_Money_Records" title="Cash Money Records">Cash Money Records</a>, and various music distribution outlets were sued for copyright infringement by Thomas Marasciullo, who claims his voice was used without permission. The rappers asked him to record some "Italian-styled spoken word recordings" in 2006. The lyrics were allegedly used on "Respect" and other tracks from the rappers' collaboration album <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Like_Father,_Like_Son_(Birdman_and_Lil_Wayne_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Like Father, Like Son (Birdman and Lil Wayne album) (page does not exist)">Like Father, Like Son</a></i> and Birdman's <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=5_*_Stunna&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="5 * Stunna (page does not exist)">5 * Stunna</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-copyright_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-copyright-169">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2011, producer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deezle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deezle (page does not exist)">Deezle</a> (Darius Harrison) sued Wayne and his parent labels Cash Money Records over unpaid royalties from <i>Tha Carter III</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2011, producer Bangladesh also filed a lawsuit against Weezy &amp; Co. over unpaid royalties as well.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early June 2011, another producer named David Kirkwood filed a lawsuit against Young Money Entertainment and Cash Money Records on claims that the labels have failed to pay him over $1.5&#160;million in royalties and production services for his work on the album, also including his songwriting on "Love Me or Hate Me", a bonus song featured only on the deluxe edition of the album.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup>
</p><p>Also in June 2011, Dallas producers <a href="/w/index.php?title=Play-N-Skillz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Play-N-Skillz (page does not exist)">Play-N-Skillz</a> filed a lawsuit against him claiming Wayne owes them at least $1&#160;million in unpaid royalties for "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Got_Money&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Got Money (page does not exist)">Got Money</a>" from his album <i>Tha Carter III</i>. The single has sold over 2 million copies since being released.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2011, Done Deal Enterprises, a production company based in Georgia, filed suit against Wayne, Universal Music Group, Cash Money Records and Young Money Entertainment, claiming copyright infringement.  The lawsuit alleges Wayne stole the song "BedRock", featured on the compilation album <i>We Are Young Money</i>, and seeks damages of $15 million.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Feuds">Feuds</span></h2>
<p><a href="/wiki/Young_Buck" title="Young Buck">Young Buck</a> released a song featuring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tony_Yayo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tony Yayo (page does not exist)">Tony Yayo</a> called "Off Parole" which insulted Lil Wayne. Young Buck said that Lil Wayne could not be angry, because Young Buck spoke the truth. Young Buck also said "You think you got a problem with Juve and B.G.; you'll have a true problem with me", referring to the Cash Money-Juvenile/B.G feud.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> One of the reasons 50 Cent stated he was dismissing Young Buck was what he called "inconsistent behavior" which included appearing on stage with Lil Wayne, then seemingly dissing him on records with G-Unit.<sup id="cite_ref-phoneleak_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-phoneleak-177">[177]</a></sup> After he was dismissed, Young Buck appeared in the music video "<a href="/w/index.php?title=My_Life_(Game_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="My Life (Game song) (page does not exist)">My Life</a>" by The Game, which featured Lil Wayne in the vocals.<sup id="cite_ref-mylife_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mylife-178">[178]</a></sup> As of 2009 Buck and Wayne have squashed their beef and also linked up to record a track "Up's and Down's" for Young Buck's <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Back_On_My_Buck_Shit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Back On My Buck Shit (page does not exist)">Back On My Buck Shit</a></i> mixtape.
</p><p>Tension between Wayne and American rapper, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pusha_T&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pusha T (page does not exist)">Pusha T</a>, had been going on for years, beginning soon after <a href="/wiki/Clipse" title="Clipse">Clipse</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Birdman_(entertainer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Birdman (entertainer) (page does not exist)">Birdman</a> worked on "What Happened to That Boy", the latter's 2002 single. In 2006, Wayne felt the Clipse song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Mr._Me_Too&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mr. Me Too (page does not exist)">Mr. Me Too</a>" was directed at him which caused more tension between the two.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> In 2012 after much speculation that Pusha T was subliminally dissing Canadian rapper and Wayne's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Young_Money&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Young Money (page does not exist)">Young Money</a> signee <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drake_(entertainer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drake (entertainer) (page does not exist)">Drake</a> in several songs, the speculation heightened after the release of Pusha T's "Exodus 23:1" song. Lil Wayne quickly responded on online social networking service <a href="/w/index.php?title=Twitter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Twitter (page does not exist)">Twitter</a> and later released a diss track titled "Goulish". In the first verse Wayne raps "Fuck Pusha T and anybody that love him / His head up his ass, I'mma have to head-butt him".<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> Pusha T has called Wayne's diss track "horrible" and said he felt it didn't deserve a response. Both men have downplayed the feud, with Wayne saying he's over it.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> However in late November, Pusha T dissed Wayne and <a href="/wiki/Birdman_(rapper)" title="Birdman (rapper)">Birdman</a> on a new <a href="/wiki/Ludacris" title="Ludacris">Ludacris</a> song titled "Tell Me What They Mad For" from his <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ludaversal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ludaversal (page does not exist)">Ludaversal</a></i> (2013) album.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early 2011, when <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">Jay-Z</a> &amp; <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">Kanye West</a>'s single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=H%E2%80%A2A%E2%80%A2M&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="H•A•M (page does not exist)">H•A•M</a>" was released, Jay-Z took shots at Lil Wayne's mentor <a href="/wiki/Birdman_(rapper)" title="Birdman (rapper)">Birdman</a>, saying "Really, you got Baby money" and "[you] ain't got <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyoncé">my lady's</a> money!".<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> On August 24, 2011, a song called "<a href="/w/index.php?title=It%27s_Good&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="It's Good (page does not exist)">It's Good</a>" by Lil Wayne (featuring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drake_(entertainer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drake (entertainer) (page does not exist)">Drake</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jadakiss" title="Jadakiss">Jadakiss</a>) was leaked online and included Lil Wayne responding "Talkin’ ‘bout baby money? I gotcha baby money. Kidnap your bitch, get that, How much you love your lady? money".<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup> Rapper <a href="/wiki/Jadakiss" title="Jadakiss">Jadakiss</a> later absolved himself of involvement in any brewing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hip_hop_rivalry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hip hop rivalry (page does not exist)">beef</a> on his official <a href="/w/index.php?title=Twitter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Twitter (page does not exist)">Twitter</a> feed.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Discography">Discography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Guerrilla_Warfare_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guerrilla Warfare (album) (page does not exist)">Guerrilla Warfare</a></i> (1999) <small>(with Hot Boys)</small>
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Block_Is_Hot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Block Is Hot (page does not exist)">Tha Block Is Hot</a></i> (1999)
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lights_Out_(Lil_Wayne_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lights Out (Lil Wayne album) (page does not exist)">Lights Out</a></i> (2000)
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=500_Degreez&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="500 Degreez (page does not exist)">500 Degreez</a></i> (2002)
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Let_%27Em_Burn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Let 'Em Burn (page does not exist)">Let 'Em Burn</a></i> (2003) <small>(with Hot Boys)</small>
</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Tha_Carter" title="Tha Carter">Tha Carter</a></i> (2004)
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Carter_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Carter II (page does not exist)">Tha Carter II</a></i> (2005)
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Like_Father,_Like_Son_(Birdman_and_Lil_Wayne_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Like Father, Like Son (Birdman and Lil Wayne album) (page does not exist)">Like Father, Like Son</a></i> (2006) <small>(with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Birdman_(entertainer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Birdman (entertainer) (page does not exist)">Birdman</a>)</small>
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Carter_III&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Carter III (page does not exist)">Tha Carter III</a></i> (2008)
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=We_Are_Young_Money&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="We Are Young Money (page does not exist)">We Are Young Money</a></i> (2009) <small>(with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Young_Money_(group)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Young Money (group) (page does not exist)">Young Money</a>)</small>
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rebirth_(Lil_Wayne_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rebirth (Lil Wayne album) (page does not exist)">Rebirth</a></i> (2010)
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am_Not_a_Human_Being&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am Not a Human Being (page does not exist)">I Am Not a Human Being</a></i> (2010)
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tha_Carter_IV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tha Carter IV (page does not exist)">Tha Carter IV</a></i> (2011)
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=I_Am_Not_a_Human_Being_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="I Am Not a Human Being II (page does not exist)">I Am Not a Human Being II</a></i> (2013)
</li>
<li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rich_Gang_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rich Gang (album) (page does not exist)">Rich Gang</a></i> (2013) <small>(with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rich_Gang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rich Gang (page does not exist)">Rich Gang</a>)</small>
</li>
</ul>
